title: Feasts and Justice
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 16 outlines God's commandments regarding the observance of key Israelite feasts—the Passover, Feast of Weeks, and Feast of Tabernacles—emphasizing remembrance of God's deliverance and provision. It also establishes principles for just leadership and warns against idolatry, underscoring holiness in worship and governance.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus and Wilderness Wanderings

keyCharacters.name: Israelite People
keyCharacters.description: The recipients of God's law, commanded to observe the feasts and live justly according to His statutes.

keyCharacters.name: Levites
keyCharacters.description: Members of the tribe of Levi who serve in the tabernacle and are included in the communal celebrations and provisions.

keyCharacters.name: Judges and Officers
keyCharacters.description: Leaders appointed to administer justice fairly throughout Israel’s tribes as commanded by God.

definitions.definition: The first month of the Hebrew calendar, marking the time of the barley harvest and the month in which Passover is observed.
A feast commemorating Israel’s deliverance from Egypt, involving the sacrifice of a lamb and eating unleavened bread.
Bread made without yeast, symbolizing purity and the haste of Israel’s departure from Egypt.
A harvest festival celebrated seven weeks after Passover, giving thanks for the grain harvest and God’s blessings.
A sacred gathering for worship and rest, often associated with feast days when no work is done.

outline.heading: The Passover and Feast of Unleavened Bread
outline.description: God commands Israel to observe the Passover in the month of Abib, sacrificing the lamb at the place He chooses and eating unleavened bread for seven days to remember their deliverance from Egypt.

outline.heading: The Feast of Weeks
outline.description: Israel is instructed to count seven weeks from the start of the grain harvest and celebrate the Feast of Weeks with offerings and rejoicing, remembering their bondage in Egypt.

outline.heading: The Feast of Tabernacles
outline.description: After the harvest of corn and wine, the Israelites are to celebrate the seven-day Feast of Tabernacles with joy and rest, acknowledging God’s provision and blessing.

outline.heading: Annual Pilgrimage and Offerings
outline.description: All Israelite males must appear before God three times a year at the appointed feasts, bringing offerings according to their blessings, fostering communal worship and dependence on God.

outline.heading: Justice in Leadership
outline.description: God commands the appointment of judges and officers to administer just and impartial judgment, warning against bribery and partiality to ensure righteousness and inheritance of the land.

outline.heading: Prohibition of Idolatry
outline.description: Israel is forbidden from planting groves or setting up images near the altar, emphasizing exclusive worship of the LORD and rejection of pagan practices.

application: Regularly remember and celebrate God's deliverance and provision through worship and thanksgiving, fostering a heart of gratitude.
Commit to living justly by supporting and respecting godly leadership and practicing fairness in personal and community decisions.
Avoid any form of idolatry or compromise in worship, keeping God alone as the center of your life and devotion.
Participate faithfully in the communal life of the church, bringing offerings and rejoicing together as a testimony of God's blessings.

keyVerses.text: That which is altogether just shalt thou follow, that thou mayest live, and inherit the land which the LORD thy God giveth thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the vital importance of pursuing justice as a means of life and blessing in the land God provides.

keyVerses.text: Three times in a year shall all thy males appear before the LORD thy God in the place which he shall choose; in the feast of unleavened bread, and in the feast of weeks, and in the feast of tabernacles: and they shall not appear before the LORD empty:
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the importance of regular, joyful worship and giving back to God as an expression of faith and dependence.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt eat no leavened bread with it; seven days shalt thou eat unleavened bread therewith, even the bread of affliction; for thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt in haste: that thou mayest remember the day when thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt all the days of thy life.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the significance of remembering God's deliverance through specific practices that shape Israel’s identity and faith.
